intro: Calycoplectus dichrus, commonly known as the two-lobed calycoplectus, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a hairy texture, while its fruits are capsule-like, splitting open to release seeds. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and for horticultural purposes.
